thread.title: Horrifying moment pilot killed as jet smashes into ground in front of horrified crowds at 'Children's Day' airshow
thread.title_full: Horrifying moment pilot killed as jet smashes into ground in front of horrified crowds at 'Children's Day' airshow

author: Richard Wheatstone
title: Horrifying moment pilot killed as jet smashes into ground in front of horrified crowds at 'Children's Day' airshow
text:
News Horrifying moment pilot killed as jet smashes into ground in front of horrified crowds at 'Children's Day' airshow Footage of the tragedy captures the shrieks from the crowd as the jet began to nosedive before crashing hear the airport runway Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Horror moment fighter jet crashes into ball of fire during air show for kids Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A pilot has been killed after his jet hurtled into the ground in front of horrified spectators at a children's airshow. 
Families were gathered for the military air even in Hat Yai, Thailand, to mark the country's annual Children's Day. 
Footage of the tragedy captures the shrieks from the crowd as the jet began to nosedive before crashing hear the airport runway. 
No-one else was injured and an investigation has been launched into the cause of the crash. Read More Crowds shrieked as the jet plunged from the sky The pilot was killed instantly 
Defence ministry spokesman Major General Kongcheep Tantravanich confirmed: "One pilot was killed in the accident this morning." 
"The Prime Minister has expressed his condolences to (the) pilot, his family and the Royal Thai Air Force." 
The 35-year-old pilot was flying a Swedish-made JAS 39 Gripen jet. Read More An investigation has been launched into the cause of the crash 
Thailand’s national Children’s Day is celebrated annually on the second Saturday of January. 
The public holiday sees military bases around the country opened to let youngsters handle guns and climb over tanks and warships. 
Many zoos and museums also allow children in for free. Like us on Facebook
